questions.text: You place a cell that is equilibrated at 160 mOsm solution, in a solution containing 70 mmol of NaCl and 50 mmol of Urea (Urea is membrane permeable). The change you would expect is:

choices.text: Cell shrinkage followed by cell swelling to original size eventually
Cell swelling followed by cell shrinking to original size eventually

questions.solution:
The cell shrinks followed by the cell swelling to original size.

 

Step 1:

It is given that the cell is equilibrated in a solution at 160 mOsm. Let us assume this as 'solution A'.

Equilibrated means that concentration of both the intracellular fluid and the solution are 160 mOsm.

As long as the cell is in 'solution A' it neither shrinks nor swells.

 

Step 2:

The cell is now placed in another solution. Let us assume this as 'solution B'.

It is given that the concentration of NaCl and urea in solution B are 70 mmol and 50 mmol respectively. We need to convert mmol to mOsm, and add them to find the osmolality of solution B.

Osmolal concentration = molar concentration X no. of freely moving particles liberated by a molecule.

  • NaCl is an ionizable solute. Each molecule of NaCl liberates two ions (one Na+ ion and one Cl- ion). Hence Osmolal concentration of NaCl = 70 mmol X 2 = 140 mOsm.
  • Urea is non ionizable. Hence, osmolal concentration of urea = 50 mmol X 1 = 50 mOsm.

∴ Osmolal concentration of solution B is 140 mOsm + 50 mOsm = 190 mOsm.

 

Step 3:

The solution B (190 mOsm) is hyperosmolal compared to intracellular fluid (160 mOsm).

When the cell is placed in solution B, the water moves from hyposmolal region (intracellular) to the hyperosmolal solution, therefore the cell initially shrinks.

However, since urea is membrane permeable, it slowly moves into the cell until the osmolality of both the intracellular fluid and the solution becomes equal.

As the urea moves in, the osmolal concentration inside the cell rises, and the water moves back into the cell. Thus the cell returns to its original size.

 

Related Pearl: Extracellular fluid vs Intracellular fluid

  Extracellular fluid Intracellular fluid
Na+ 142 mEq/L 10 mEq/L
K+ 4 mEq/L 140 mEq/L
Ca++ 2.4 mEq/L 0.0001 mEq/L
Cl- 103 mEq/L 4 mEq/L
HCO3- 28 mEq/L 10 mEq/L
PO₄³⁻ 4 mEq/L 75 mEq/L
Glucose 90 mg/dL 0-20 mg/dL
Proteins 2 g/dl (5mEq/L) 16 g/dL (40 mEq/L)
pH 7.4  7.0
Osmolarity 282 mOsm/L 281 mOsm/L
Major Cation Na+ K+
Major Anion Cl- Phosphate
Buffer HCO3-

Protein

Phosphate
Most osmotically active ion Na+ K+

questions.text: A patient has a ​blood glucose level of 200 mg/dL and GFR of 90 ml/min. What is the amount of glucose excreted if the transport maximum of the patient is as shown below?
questions.solution:
The amount of Glucose excreted in the above scenario is 30 mg/min.

Normally, glucose is filtered into the tubular secretion. The filtered glucose is reabsorbed by glucose transportes in the proximal tubule of the nephron. When blood glucose levels are normal all the glucose is absorbed back into the blood, and very minute quantities are excreted in urine.

The maximum rate at which the glucose can be reabsorbed by the transporters is known as the transport maxiumum (Tm). When Tm is reached, all the glucose transporters gets saturated and cannot reabsorb more glucose.

The renal threshold for glucose is the plasma glucose concentration beyond which the filtered glucose exceeds the ability of the tubule to reaborb (Tm), such that, the excess of filtered glucose is excreted in the urine.

 

Calculation:

Step 1: Calculate total filtered glucose:

In this question,

  • GFR = 90 ml/min
  • Plasma glucose concentration = 200 mg/dL= 2 mg/ml (1dL=100 ml).
  • Total filtered glucose = GFR X Plasma glucose concentration.

= 90 ml/min X 2 mg/ml
= 180 mg/min.

Step 2: Check transport maximum:

In the above question transport maximum is 150 mg/min.

Step 3: Calculate the excretion:

Excretion = Total filtered glucose - Total reabsorbed glucose (Transport Maximum)

= 180-150 mg/min
= 30 mg/min

questions.text: A 55-year-old patient presents with claudication in the right lower limb. Arterial doppler reveals a narrowing of the popliteal artery. The diameter was found to be reduced to one-third. How much will the blood flow reduce by?
questions.solution:
The blood flow through the vessel decreases by 81 times.

The relationship between the flow in a long narrow tube, the viscosity of the fluid, and the radius of the tube is expressed mathematically in the formula called as Poiseuille's law :

Blood flow (F) inside the vessel depends on: 

  • Pressure difference: directly proportional
  • Viscosity: inversely proportional
  • Radius: directly proportional to the fourth power
  • Length of the vessel: inversely proportional

Here, the diameter is reduced to 1/3rd, implying the radius is also reduced to 1/3rd. Therefore, the flow decreases by (1/3) 4 = 1/81

questions.text: In the given circuit of blood flow, the inward flow pressure is 100 mmHg and the outward flow pressure is 10 mmHg. Each of the parallel circuit of capillaries have resistance of 5 mmHg/mL/min. Calculate the flow across the circuit of blood vessels.
questions.solution:
In the given circuit of the blood flow, three capillary resistances are connected in parallel,

Hence the net resistance (R) can be calculated as

1 / R = 1/R1 + 1/R2 + 1/R3

1 / R = 1/5 + 1/5 + 1/5

Therefore,

Net resistance (R) = 5/3 mmHg/mL/min

Flow in any portion of the vascular system is equal to the effective perfusion pressure in that portion divided by the net resistance.

The effective perfusion pressure is the mean intraluminal pressure at the arterial end (inward flow pressure) minus the mean pressure at the venous end (outward flow pressure).

According to Ohm’s law,

The flow in any circuit can be calculated by the formula,

Flow = (100-10) / (5/3)

= 90 × 3/5

= 18 × 3

= 54 mL/min

questions.text: Calculate the ejection fraction from the given left ventricular pressure-volume curve:
questions.solution:
The ejection fraction as calculated from the above volume pressure curve is 60%.

The ejection fraction is defined as the percentage of the end-diastolic ventricular volume that is ejected with each stroke.

Thus, EF = Volume ejected / End diastolic volume × 100

The volume ejected can be obtained, by subtracting the end systolic volume from end diastolic volume. Thus,

EF = End diastolic volume (EDV) − End systolic volume (ESV) / End diastolic volume (EDV) × 100

In the above volume pressure curve of left ventricle,

EDV = 130 ml

ESV = 52 ml

Substituting these values in the above equation we get,

EF = (130 − 52 / 130) × 100

 = (3 / 5) × 100

 = 0.6 × 100

 = 60%

Related information:

The ejection fraction is a valuable index of the ventricular function. It is measured by injecting radionuclide-labeled red blood cells and imaging the volume of the blood at the end of diastole and the end of systole (equilibrium radionuclide angiocardiography), or by computed tomography.

The normal left ventricular ejection fraction is 50% to 70%.

In heart failure, ejection fraction may be preserved or reduced,

  • Preserved ejection fraction (HFpEF) – also referred to as diastolic heart failure. The heart muscle contracts normally but the ventricles do not relax as they should during ventricular filling (or when the ventricles relax).
  • Reduced ejection fraction (HFrEF) – also referred to as systolic heart failure. The heart muscle does not contract effectively and less oxygen-rich blood is pumped out to the body.

LVEF Assessment:

The American college of cardiology (ACC), gives the cardiac function and their corresponding ejection fractions

  • Hyperdynamic = LVEF greater than 70%
  • Normal = LVEF 50% to 70% (midpoint 60%)
  • Mild dysfunction = LVEF 40% to 49% (midpoint 45%)
  • Moderate dysfunction = LVEF 30% to 39% (midpoint 35%)
  • Severe dysfunction = LVEF less than 30%

questions.text: If the tidal volume is 500 mL, PeCO2 is 30 mmHg and PaCO2 is 45 mmHg, calculate the dead space?
questions.solution:
The Bohr-enghoff equation is used to calculate physiological dead space/total dead space.

The original Bohr equation required measurement of the alveolar partial pressure of CO2 (PACO2).

Later Enghoff modified the equation and replaced the PACO2 with PaCO2 (partial pressure of CO2 in arterial blood). Enghoff's modification of Bohr equation is:

Where,

  • VD is the physiological dead space
  • VT is the tidal volume
  • PaCO2 is the partial pressure of CO2 in the arterial blood
  • PeCO2 is the average partial pressure of CO2 in the entire expired air.  

Substituting the values:

Vd=(45-30/45) x 500=166.66 ml

questions.text: A person with normal lung at sea level (760 mm Hg) is breathing 50% oxygen. With a normal respiratory quotient of 0.8, what is the approximate alveolar Po2 (in mmHg)?
questions.solution:
Alveolar gas equation is used to calculate partial pressure of O2 in alveolar air.

It is given by the formula:

Where

  • PAO2 = Alveolar PO2 (mm Hg)
  • PIO2 = PO2 in inspired air (mm Hg)
  • PACO2 = Alveolar PCO2 (mm Hg), which is normally 40mmHg
  • R = Respiratory exchange ratio or respiratory quotient (CO2 production/O2 consumption)
  • Correction factor is usually negligible.

Step 1: In the question PO2 in inspired air is not given directly. It has to be calculated using the formula:

PIO2 = FIO2 (PB - PH20)

Where

  • PIO2 = PO2 in inspired air (mm Hg)
  • FIO2 = Fraction of inspired O2 (50% or 0.5)
  • PB = Barometric pressure (760 mmHg)
  • PH2O = Water vapour pressure (47 mmHg)

Substituting the values:

PIO2 = 0.5 (760 - 47) = 0.5 × 713 = 356.5 mmHg

Step 2:

PAO2 = PiO2 – (Pco2/R) = 356.5 – (40/0.8) = 356.5 – 50 = 306.5 mmHg.

questions.text: 500 mg of mannitol was injected out of which 10% is excreted. After equilibrium, plasma concentration is 3.2 mg/100 ml. Calculate ECF Volume (L).
questions.solution:
The volume of distribution can be calculated using the formula:

  • V = volume of compartment
  • Amount injected = 500 mg
  • Amount of indicator excreted = 10% of 500 mg = 50mg
  • Plasma concentration of the indicator = 3.2 mg/100mL

Calculation:

2nd method : 

Mannitol is a substance which leaves blood vessel but can't enter the cell. Therefore, after attaining equilibrium, conc. of mannitol is same in plasma and interstitial fluid 

Therefore, by applying dye-dilution technique, mannitol can be used to measure the volume of ECF (x)

Since, 10% is excreted and 10% of 500mg is 50 mg, the amount of mannitol diluted in ECF is 450 mg (500 - 50) i.e, 450 mg is present in x 

From the given values, 3.2 mg is present in 100 ml, which can be re-written as

      3.2/100 = 450/x

Therefore x = 450 * 100 / 3.2 mL

                    = 14,062.5 mL

                    = 14 L

Clinical :

IV Mannitol is used to treat cerebral oedema (since, it doesn't cross cell membrane, it extracts fluid from brain cells), whereas it is contra-indicated in pulmonary edema (here the fluid collection is in the interstitial space)

questions.text: In a sample of DNA if adenine is 23%, what will be the amount of guanine?
questions.solution:
In a sample of DNA, if adenine is 23%, guanine will be 27%.

This is based on Chargaff’s rule which states that the number of purines is equal to the number of pyrimidines.

Purines include adenine and guanine. Pyrimidines include thymine and cytosine. The two strands of DNA are complementary to each other. So, the adenine of one strand will pair with thymine of the opposite strand, while guanine will pair with cytosine.

  • Step 1:

No of adenine = No of thymine

So adenine + thymine = 46%

Guanine + cytosine = 54%

  • Step 2:

No of guanine = No of cytosine

So, amount of guanine = 54/2 = 27%

questions.text: On infusion of a large volume of blood, the MAP rises from 100 mmHg to 175 mmHg. Due to the baroreceptor feedback mechanism, the MAP falls down to 125 mmHg. Calculate the gain of the feedback system.
questions.solution:
The gain of the feedback system in the above case is -2.

The gain of the system is then calculated by using the following formula:

Gain = C/E

Here, C is correction achieved from the deviated value and E is the remaining error post-correction.

Calculation

  • The original value in the given case is 100 mmHg.
  • The deviated value in the given case is 175 mmHg.
  • The corrected value in the given case is 125 mmHg.
  • C is given by correction achieved from deviated value, Corrected value - Deviated value = 125 - 175 = -50 mmHg.
  • E is given by the remaining error post-correction, Corrected value - Original value = 125 - 100 = 25 mmHg.
  • Gain = -50/25 = -2.

The negative symbol indicates that the homeostatic mechanism acts in a direction opposite to the initial deviation.

questions.text: The lab values of a patient reveal a total cholesterol level of  300 mg/dl, TG - 150 mg/dl and HDL - 25 mg/dl . What would be the LDL value?
questions.solution:
The LDL value in the above scenario will be 245 mg/dl.

According to Friedewald’s equation

LDL-C = TC - HDL-C - (TG/5) 

Where

  • HDL-C: High-density lipoprotein cholesterol
  • LDL-C: Low-density lipoprotein cholesterol
  • TG: Triglycerides
  • TC: Total cholesterol

Substituting the values:

LDL-C = 300 - 25 - (150/5) = 300-55 = 245 mg/dl

Note:

VLDL-C(Very low-density lipoprotein cholesterol) = TG/5

questions.text: In a reaction, the substrate is available in a concentration that is 1000 times the Km value of the enzyme.  After 9 minutes of reaction, 1% of substrate is converted to product (12 microgram/ml). If the concentration of the enzyme is changed to 1/3 and concentration of substrate is doubled, what is the time taken to convert the substrate into the same amount of product that i.e. 12 microgram/ml?
questions.solution:
The time taken for the formation of the same amount of product is 27 minutes.

In this reaction, the substrate concentration becomes 1000 times i.e much greater than the Km value. Thus, the rate of this reaction is equal to Vmax and is thus independent of the substrate concentration i.e. it follows zero-order kinetics. Thus, doubling the substrate concentration does not change the velocity of the reaction i.e. it remains as Vmax.

No matter the substrate concentration, the rate of the reaction is directly proportional to the concentration of the enzyme. In this situation the enzyme concentration becomes 1/3rd. Thus, the velocity of the reaction (Vmax) also becomes 1/3rd. This means that the time taken for the formation of the same amount of product will become tripled i.e 9 × 3 = 27 minutes.

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman had severe blood loss during delivery 2-days ago. Her current hemoglobin is 5 gm/dL and reticulocyte count is 9%. What is her corrected reticulocyte count?
questions.solution:
In the given scenario, the corrected reticulocyte count is 3.

It is given by the following formula:

Corrected reticulocyte count = Reticulocyte count × (patient's hemoglobin or hematocrit ⁄ standard hemoglobin or hematocrit)

So, in this case, the corrected reticulocyte count = 9×5/15  = 9/3  = 3

This formula corrects for hemoglobin. It will show you if the patient is making enough reticulocytes for the degree of anemia present. As the hemoglobin drops, reticulocytes increase from the normal range of 0.5–2.0%.

The standard reference range of hemoglobin concentration in females is 12-15 g/dl. Accordingly, in this scenario, corrected reticulocyte count would range between 3-3.75%. So, the best answer to this question remains option C.

Absolute reticulocyte count is the percentage of red cells that are reticulocytes (normal is about 0.5 – 2.0%). However, it does not reflect the fact that as the hemoglobin drops, there should be more reticulocytes, percentage-wise (for example, at a hemoglobin of 5, you should have a much higher percentage of reticulocytes than you should at a hemoglobin of 10). To take this into account, we use corrected reticulocyte count.

Reticulocyte Index = Corrected reticulocyte count / maturation factor

This corrects for the longer life span of prematurely released reticulocytes in the blood which is a phenomenon of increased red blood cell production.

Hematocrit Maturation factor
≥ 35% 1.0
35% > Hct ≥ 25% 1.5
25% > Hct ≥ 20% 2.0
< 20% 2.5

questions.text: If a drug is known to be distributed into the total body water, what dose of the drug is needed to obtain an initial plasma level of 5 mg/L in a male patient weighing 70 kg?
questions.solution:
The drug dose needed to achieve initial plasma concentration is the loading dose, which is 210 mg in this case.

The equation for loading dose or the volume of the distribution equation can be used for calculation.
Loading Dose = Vd × Cp

Since the patient weighs 70 kg and 60% of his body weight is water, he has 42 L (70 L x 60%) of total body water.
Loading Dose = 42 L × 5 mg/L = 210 mg.

questions.text: Oral digoxin is being given to a 65-year-old male patient with congestive heart failure as a maintenance dose to gradually digitalize him. A target plasma concentration of 0.70 ng/mL is decided upon. The digoxin clearance for this particular individual is calculated as 60 mL/min. Knowing that the oral bioavailability of digoxin is 70%, what is the dosing rate in this patient?
questions.solution:
The dosing rate in this patient is 60 ng/min.

The oral bioavailability of digoxin is 70% (F = 0.7) and the required target plasma concentration (Cp) is 0.70 ng/mL. CL is the clearance of digoxin which is 60 mL/min.

Hence, the appropriate dose rate for this patient can be calculated as:

Dosing rate = Target Cp x CL/F

= [0.70 ng/mL × 60 mL/min] ÷ [0.7]

= 60 ng/min

questions.text: How much drug will remain at the end of 6 hours when a patient is given 200 mg drug, 75 mg excreted in 90 min and if the drug follows first-order kinetics?
questions.solution:
In first order kinetics, a constant fraction of the drug is excreted in a given time. 

Since 75 mg of 200 mg is excreted in 90 minutes, the fraction of drug excreted in each 90 mins is 75/200, which is 3/8. Thus, the fraction of the drug that remains in the body is 5/8. 

There will be 4 cycles of excretion of the drug (6 hours = 360 mins, and 360/90 = 4). Thus, with a starting dose of 200mg, the drug remaining in the body after 4 hours will be:

200 x 5/8 x 5/8 x 5/8 x 5/8 = 30.5mg

Alternate way to calculate: 

75 mg of 200 mg is excreted in 90 minutes, thus 75/200 = 0.375 is eliminated 

After 90 minutes; 200 mg-75 mg = 125 mg remains.
The second 90 minutes (after 180 minutes) = 125 x 0.375 = 46.875 mg is eliminated, and 125-46.875 = 78.125 mg remains
The third 90 minutes (after 270 minutes) = 78.125 x 0.375 = 29.297 mg is eliminated, and 78.125-29.297 = 48.828 remains
The fourth 90 minutes (after 360 minutes) = 48.828 x 0.375 = 18.310 mg is eliminated, 48.828-18.310 = 30.518 mg remains after 6 hours. 

Related Pearl: Zero order vs First order kinetics of drugs

Zero order

First order

Constant amount of drug is eliminated per unit time

 Constant fraction of drug is eliminated per unit time

Rate of elimination is independent of plasma concentration

 Rate of elimination is proportional to the plasma concentration

Clearance is more at low concentration and less at high concentration

 Clearance remains constant 

Half-life is less at low concentration and more at high concentration

 Half-life remains constant

Very few drugs follow zero-order kinetics, e.g.(WATT Power)

  • Warfarin
  • Alcohol, Aspirin
  • Tolbutamide
  • Theophylline 
  • Phenytoin

 

 Most of the drugs follow first order kinetics

questions.text: Calculate the therapeutic index of a drug whose dose-response curves are plotted as shown below:
questions.solution:
The therapeutic index is 4.

In the above graph,

Median lethal dose (LD50) = 400

Median effective dose (ED50) = 100

Therapeutic index (TI) = LD50/ED50.

Hence,

Therapeutic index (TI ) = 400/100 = 4

Clinically, the therapeutic range bound by the dose that produces the minimal therapeutic effect and the dose that produces the maximal acceptable adverse effect is more relevant.

questions.text:
You have started an infusion of drug Y in a patient at a rate of 200 mg/hr. Drug Y has Vd of 100 litres and clearance of 100 mL/min. What will be the drug concentration at a steady state?

Vd- Volume of distribution
questions.solution:
Steady state concentration (Css) for this drug Y is 33.33mg/L.

Steady-state concentration is the amount of drug administered is equal to the amount of drug eliminated within one dosing interval resulting in a plateau or constant drug plasma concentration, with the plasma concentration fluctuating between a minimum and maximum. In the case of intravenous infusion, the equation is: 

Steady state concentration (Css) = Rate of infusion ÷ Clearance

In the above question,

Rate of infusion = 200 mg/hr, Volume of distribution (Vd)= 100 L, Clearance = 100 mL/min

Clearance = 100 x 60 mL/hr = 6000 mL/hr = 6L/hr (converted from mL/min to L/hr)

Therefore, on substituting these values to the above equation, 

Css = (200 mg/hr) ÷ (6L/hr) = 100/3 = 33.33 mg/L

questions.text:
The clearance of a drug which follows first-order kinetics (in one compartment model) is 0.2 L/min and volume of distribution is 40 L. What is the t1/2 of that drug?

t1/2: half-life
questions.solution:
The t1/2 of the drug would be 140 minutes.

Plasma half-life (t1/2) is the time required for the plasma concentration or the amount of a drug in the body to be reduced by 50%. It depends on its clearance and volume of distribution. 

t1/2 = 0.693 x Vd/CL

where, 

  • Vd - volume of distribution
  • CL - clearance.

In the given question, drug clearance (CL) = 0.2 L/min and Vd = 40 L

We can take 0.693 approximately as 0.7

Substituting,

t1/2 = 0.7 x 40 /0.2

t1/2 = 0.7 x 200

t1/2 = 140 minutes

Clinical implications: Half-life determines the duration of the drug effect. It also indicates whether the accumulation of the drug will occur under multiple dosage regimens, thereby making it is essential to decide on the appropriate dosing interval.

questions.text: You have to give 180 mg of ceftriaxone to a patient in a 2 ml syringe that has 10 divisions per ml. The concentration of the drug in the vial is 500 mg/5 ml. How many divisions should be filled in 2 ml of the syringe to give 180 mg?
questions.solution:
The 2ml syringe should be filled up to 18 divisions to deliver 180 mg ceftriaxone to the patient. 

Concentration of ceftriaxone in the vial is: 500mg/5ml = 100mg/1mL.

Since 100mg is present in 1 mL, we can calculate the volume required for 180mg:   180mg ÷ 100mg/1 mL = 1.8 mL. Thus, we need to draw 1.8 mL of solution into the syringe.

The given 2 mL syringe has 10 divisions per mL. Therefore, the total number of divisions in 2 mL is 20 divisions. Since 1 mL = 10 divisions, the required 1.8mL corresponds to: 

1.8mL x 10 divisions/ mL = 18 divisions. Hence, to administer 180 mg of ceftriaxone, the syringe should be filled up to 18 divisions.

questions.text: Calculate hepatic clearance of a drug with hepatic blood flow of 2000 mL/min and hepatic extraction ratio of 0.5.
questions.solution:
The hepatic clearance of the given drug is 1000 mL/min.

Clearance of a drug by an organ is the difference between the rate of presentation of the drug to the organ and the rate of exit of the drug from the organ. It is calculated by the equation:

CLorgan = Q x E

Where, 

  • Q - Organ blood flow 
  • E - Extraction ratio (organ-specific)

The question shows that the hepatic blood flow (Q) is 2000 mL/min and the hepatic extraction ratio (E) is 0.5.

Substituting the values in the above equation, 

CLorgan = 2000 X 0.5 = 1000 mL/min

Note: The extraction ratio (E) is the fraction of the drug that is removed from the blood by the eliminating organ.

Extraction ratio (E) = CA-CV/CA

Where,

  • CA is the concentration of drug presented to the organ
  • CA-CV is the drug removed by the organ

questions.text: Crown Rump Length is 21 cm, length of lower limb is 10 cm, gestational age of the fetus will be:
questions.solution:
Gestational age of this fetus is 6-7 months.

Crown rump length + length of lower limb = crown heel length

Rule of Haase enables the estimation of the age of the fetus in lunar months from its crown-heel length (in cm).

According to the rule,

  • Age in months = Square root of crown-heel length (when the crown-heel length is 25 cm or less/ first 5 months).
  • Age in months = crown-heel length divided by 5 (when the crown-heel length is more than 25 cm/ last 5 months).

Here, crown heel length = Crown rump + lower limb length = 31 cm.

Hence, gestational age = 31 / 5 = 6-7 months.

questions.text: A lens has a focal length of 10 cms. What is the dioptric power of the lens?
questions.solution:
The dioptric power of the lens is reciprocal to its focal length, provided that the unit of measuring length is a metre.

Thus, 

D = 1 / f

Where,

D is the dioptric power of the lens, and f is the focal length in metre.

The focal length of the lens in the above question is 10 cms which is equal to 0.1 m.

Substituting the above value in the equation we get the dioptric power as,

D = 1 / 0.1 = 10 D

questions.text: A population of 25000 were subjected to a screening test to detect lung cancer. The prevalence of the disease was 20% among the population. The test could correctly detect the disease in only 80% of the diseased people. Another 5% of the normal people were also identified as diseased by the test. Considering the population doubles in the next 5 years while the prevalence rate remains the same, which of the following with respect to screening test would be true?

choices.text: The likelihood of a diseased person being detected as positive is 16 times as compared to a normal person
The sensitivity would remain the same but negative predictive value would change
The sensitivity of the test will be equal to the negative predictive value of the test in 5 years
The specificity of the test will be double that of sensitivity

questions.solution:
The positive likelihood ratio (the likelihood of a diseased person being detected as positive is as compared to a normal person) for the given screening test is 16.

For the given data the following table can be constructed.

  Disease positive Disease negative  
Test Positive 4000 (TP) 1000 (FP) 5000
Test Negative 1000 (FN) 19000 (TN) 20000
  5000 20000 25000

From the table, the following values can be calculated:

  • Sensitivity: TP/ (TP + FN) * 100 = 4000/5000 * 100 = 80%
  • Specificity: TN/ (TN+ FP) * 100 = 19000/20000 * 100 = 95%
  • Positive Likelihood ratio: Sens / (1- Spec) = 0.8 / 0.05 = 16
  • Negative Likelihood ratio: (1-Sens) / Spec = 0.2 / 0.95 = 0.21
  • Positive Predictive Value: TP/ (TP + FP) * 100 = 4000/5000 * 100 = 80%
  • Negative Predictive Value: TN / (TN+ FN) * 100 = 19000/20000 * 100 = 95%

If the population doubles, and the prevalence is the same, there is no change in the values as can be seen below:

  Disease positive Disease negative  
Test Positive  8000 (TP) 2000 (FP) 10000
Test Negative 2000 (FN) 38000 (TN) 40000
  10,000 40,000 50000
  • Sensitivity: TP/ (TP + FN) * 100 = 8000/10000 * 100 = 80%
  • Specificity: TN/ (TN+ FP) * 100 = 38000/40000 * 100 = 95%
  • Positive Likelihood ratio: Sens / (1- Spec) = 0.8 / 0.05 = 16
  • Negative Likelihood ratio: (1-Sens) / Spec = 0.2 / 0.95 = 0.21
  • Positive Predictive Value: TP/ (TP + FP) * 100 = 8000/10000 * 100 = 80%
  • Negative Predictive Value: TN / (TN+ FN) * 100 = 38000/40000 * 100 = 95%

Related Pearl: Validity of a Screening Test

  • Validity/ accuracy of a screening test depends upon the sensitivity, specificity, and predictive accuracy of the test.
  • It represents the closeness to a true value/ actual value.
  • These are the inherent properties of a screening test.
  • PPV and NPV are dependent on the Prevalence of disease.
  • Sensitivity & Specificity are independent of prevalence of disease.
Formulae 
Sensitivity      TP    
TP + FN
Specificity      TN    
FP + TN
Predictive value of a positive test (PPV)      TP    
TP + FP
Predictive value of a negative test (NPV)      TN     
TN + FN
Percentage of false positives      FP     
FP + TN
Percentage of false negatives      FN     
TP + FN
  • PPV varies directly with prevalence
  • NPV varies inversely with prevalence

questions.text: What is the angle subtended by the optotype on the second line of Snellen’s chart when viewed from a distance of 6 meters?
questions.solution:
The angle subtended by the optotype (individual letters on the chart) on the second line of Snellen’s chart in the above case would be 30 minutes of arc.

The second line on Snellen’s chart corresponds to a distance of 36 meters. When viewed from a 6m distance, it is denoted as visual acuity 6/36. Where,

  • The numerator (6) denotes the distance from which the patient is actually viewing it
  • The denominator (36) denotes the distance at which it should be ideally viewed. It denotes the distance at which each stroke of the letter would subtend the minimum angle of resolution (MAR) of one minute of arc.

MAR = 1/Visual acuity

Each letter is shaped such that it can be placed in a square, the sides of which are five times the breadth of individual limbs of the letters. Hence, the angle subtended by the optotype= MAR x 5

For eg: At exactly 6 meters distance from the patient, the letters on the 6/6 line shall subtend 5 minutes of arc (such that the individual limbs of the letters subtend 1 minute of arc).

The equation to calculate the minimum angle of resolution (MAR) is given as follows:

For the given question,

MAR = 1/ 6/36
MAR = 36/6
MAR = 6 minutes of arc

Hence, the angle subtended by the entire letter is 6 × 5 = 30 minutes of arc.

questions.text: In a subcentre area with a crude birth rate (CBR) of 20, what would be the expected number of antenatal care (ANC) registrations by the village health nurse (VHN) in a year?
questions.solution:
• According to the Indian Public Health Standards (IPHS) laid down by the Government of India, a subcentre is to serve a population of 5000 in plains.
  • In this scenario, the CBR is 20.
  • Probable number of pregnancies (Y) = Birth rate x population of the area / 1000 = 20 x 5000/1000 = 100.
  • But, we add a correction factor of 10% to adjust for pregnancy wastage in the form of abortions or stillbirths. 
  • Thus, total number of expected pregnancies= Y + 10% of Y= 110
  • As all the pregnancies are not registered, and at any given time an ANM should have atleast half the expected pregnancies registered with her, the number of ANC registrations is taken as 50% of the expected pregnancies.
  • Therefore, Total ANC registrations = total number of expected pregnancies/2 = 55
  • Hence, the closest answer is 60.

questions.text: Hemoglobin levels were measured in 200 pregnant women. The results showed a mean hemoglobin level of 10.5 g/dL with a standard deviation of 0.5 g/dL. Assuming that the distribution is normal, how many women will have hemoglobin levels <9.5 g/dL?
questions.solution:
In the given population, 5 women will have hemoglobin (Hb) levels < 9.5 g/dL.

In a normal distribution, the distribution of values around the mean is as follows:

  • 68% of the distribution falls within ±1 SD of the mean. 
  • 95% of the distribution falls within ±2 SD of the mean. 
  • 99.7% of the distribution falls within ±3 SD of the mean.

In a normal distribution, 2 SD from the mean will have 95% of the participants. Therefore, 95% of pregnant women will have Hb levels of 10.5±2*0.5 = 10.5±1 =  9.5-11.5 g/dL.

The remaining 2.5% of women will have Hb >11.5 g/dL and 2.5% of women will have Hb level <9.5 g/dL.

2.5% of 200 = 5. Hence, 5 women will have Hb of <9.5 g/dL.

Related Pearl: Normal Distribution

The normal distribution curve is the most common shape taken by continuous data distributions. It is also called bell curve (bell-shaped) or Gaussian distribution after mathematician Karl Friedrich Gauss.

The following is an image of three different normal distribution curves.

Salient features of the standard normal distribution:

  • Defined by two parameters: the mean and the standard deviation
  • Has mean of 0 and a standard deviation of 1
  • Mean = median = mode
  • Symmetric and have bell-shaped curves with a single peak
  • Total area under the curve is 1
  • Frequency of values is more around the center and less around the tails
  • No skew in the curve
  • Data like blood pressure, heights, IQ scores, etc. form a normal distribution
  • The empirical rule of a normal distribution:
    • Approximately 68% of the distribution falls within one standard deviation of the mean (mean ± 1 SD)
    • Approximately 95% of the distribution falls within two standard deviations of the mean (mean ± 2 SD)
    • Approximately 99.7% of the distribution falls within three standard deviations of the mean (mean ± 3 SD)

questions.text: In a given population, total births in a year are 5100. 100 babies were still born and 250 neonates died within 28 days of life. What is the neonatal mortality rate in this population?
questions.solution:
• Neonatal mortality rate = Number of deaths of children under 28 days of age in a year x 1000/Total live births in the same year
  • The total live births in this scenario is 5100 – 100 = 5000 live births
  • NMR = 250 x 1000/5000 = 50

Related Pearl: Neonatal Mortality Rate

  • Neonatal deaths are those that occur during the neonatal period, commencing at birth and ending at 28 completed days after birth.
  • NMR = Number of deaths of children under 28 days of age in a year x 1000/Total live births in the same year
  • Main causes of neonatal death are prematurity (leading cause), birth asphyxia, intrapartum-related complications, sepsis, pneumonia, congenital anomalies, tetanus, diarrhea, etc.
  • India’s NMR  is 20 per 1000 live births (SRS 2020)

questions.text: In a population of 100, prevalence of candida glabrata was found to be 80%. If the investigator has to repeat the prevalence with 95% confidence, what will the prevalence be?
questions.solution:
Confidence intervals(CI) for population proportion (95% confidence).

CI = p +/- 2 x SEP

Where, SEP (sample error of proportion) =√pq/n

Hence,

In the given question :

  • p (prevalence) = 0.80 (80%) 
  • q = 1-p = 1-0.80= 0.20
  • n (sample size) = 100

questions.text: The incidence of bladder carcinoma in a population was found to be 5 times higher in smokers than in non-smokers. What is the attributable risk?
questions.solution:
The attributable risk, in this case, will be 80%.

Let the incidence of bladder carcinoma in non-smokers (non-exposed) be x. Therefore, the incidence in smokers (exposed) will be 5x.

According to the formula, attributable risk (AR) is given as follows:

AR (%) = [(IP exposed - IP non-exposed)/ IP exposed] x100, where IP = Incidence proportion

= [(5x - x)/5x] x 100

= 4x/5x x 100

= 80%

Thus, the attributable risk is 80%.

Related Pearl: Relative and Attributable Risk

Relative Risk:

  • Ratio of incidence of disease or death among exposed to that among the non-exposed is called relative risk (RR).
  • It is also called risk ratio.
  • It is the direct measure of the strength of association between suspected cause and effect in cohort studies.
  • RR < 1 indicates inverse association(protective effect)
  • RR = 1 indicates no association.
  • RR > 1 indicates positive association.
  • RR of 2 indicates a 100% increase in risk.
  • Relative risk calculation (RR) = [ a/(a+b) ]/ [ c/(c+d) ] where, 
  Cancer
Exposure   yes no
yes a b
no c d

 

Attributable Risk:

  • Attributable risk (AR) is the difference in incidence rates or proportions of disease or death between an exposed and non-exposed group.
  • It is expressed in percentage and gives the extent to which the disease can be attributed to the exposure in a cohort study.

questions.text:
The smoking history for the past 6 years of a patient with emphysema is given in the table below. If a pack has 20 cigarettes, what is the mean, median and mode of the given data?
 Year   No of cigarettes per day
2015 Quarter pack
2016 Half a pack
2017 Half a pack
2018 Half a pack
2019 One pack
2020 Two packs
questions.solution:
The distribution in this scenario in terms of the number of cigarettes smoked is 5, 10, 10, 10, 20, 40.

The mean here is ∑x/n = 95/6 = 15.833 rounded off to 16.

The median here is the central value = average of 3rd and 4th values since the distribution has an even number of values. This comes to (10 + 10) / 2 = 10.

The mode here is 10 which has a frequency of 3 in the given dataset.

Related Pearl: The Mean (Arithmetic) in Biostatistics

  • The mean is also called the average or arithmetic mean.
  • It is the sum of all elements in the distribution divided by the number of all the elements in it.
  • It is usually denoted by μ in a population and by x̄ (x-bar) in a sample.
  • The formula for sample mean is given as:

where the sigma sign denotes summation and n is the total number of elements.

  • The arithmetic mean responds to the exact value of every element in the distribution.
  • This makes it over-sensitive to extreme values, i.e., outliers thus making it an inappropriate measure for skewed distributions.
  • The advantage of the arithmetic mean is that if repeated samples are taken from the same populations, they will have very similar means, i.e., the measure of central tendency that best resists the influence of fluctuation between samples is the mean.
  • The mean can be calculated only on quantitative data on an interval or a ratio scale.

Related Pearl: The Median in Biostatistics

  • The median is the central element in a distribution when all the elements are arranged in order.
  • In a distribution that has an odd number of elements, the median is the middle value.
  • In a distribution that has an even number of elements, the median is the average of the middle values, i.e., the arithmetic mean of the two middle values.
  • The median is not sensitive to extreme values, i.e., outliers and thus it is preferred measure of location for very skewed distributions.
  • The drawback of the median is that it doesn’t respond to the actual values of the elements but only to the number of values above or below it.
  • The median is the same as the 50th centile.
  • It is sometimes symbolized by Mdn.
  • The median can be arrived at in ordinal, interval and ratio data scales.

Related Pearl: The Mode in Biostatistics

  • The mode is most frequently occurring observed value in a distribution.
  • A distribution with a single mode is called unimodal.
  • If two values occur with the highest frequency, then the distribution is bimodal.
  • If more than two values occur with the highest frequency, then the distribution is multimodal.
  • The mode is the preferred measure of central tendency for nominal data.
  • It is sometimes symbolized by Mo.
  • Mode can be arrived at from all data scales, i.e., nominal, ordinal, ratio and interval.

questions.text: There are 50 patients admitted in a ward of your medical college. Here 20 are girls and 30 are boys. Out of this, 10 girls and 20 boys require surgery. What is the probability that a randomly selected boy and girl both require surgery?
questions.solution:
In the given scenario, the probability that a randomly selected boy and girl both require surgery is 1/3.

First, we have to calculate the probability of picking the boys requiring surgery and the girls requiring surgery separately. These are mutually exclusive events.

In this scenario, the probability of correctly picking a girl requiring surgery is p(A)=10/20= 1/2

The probability of correctly picking a boy requiring surgery is p(B)=20/30= 2/3

Next, we apply the multiplication rule of probability.

The probability of picking boys and girls that require surgery,

p(A and B)= p(A) x p(B)= ½ x ⅔ = 2/6= 1/3.

Related Pearl: Probability

  • Expressed as a decimal fraction never as a percentage. Denoted by p
  • Must lie between 0 (zero probability) and 1 (absolute certainty).
  • Probability of an event cannot be negative.
  • The probability of an event not occurring (q) is q= 1-p

Rule

Description

Example

The Addition Rule

(p) of any one of several particular events occurring = the sum of their individual probabilities, provided the events cannot both happen and are mutually exclusive.

Probability of picking a heart card from a deck is 0.25 and that of picking a club is 0.25. Thus the p (hearts or clubs) is 0.25 + 0.25 = 0.50.

The Multiplication Rule

(p) of two or more statistically independent events all occurring is = product of their individual probabilities.

If the lifetime probability of a person developing a lung neoplasm is 0.25 and the life time probability of developing dementia is 0.01, then the p (lung neoplasm and dementia) is 0.25 x 0.01 = 0.0025.

The Binomial Distribution

 

(p) of the occurrence of a specific combination of mutually exclusive independent events.

The events for which binomial distribution is used have only two outcomes like yes or no, tall or short, male or female, etc.

 

Widely used in genetic counseling.

questions.text: Each value of a study sample is multiplied by 10. What would be the new standard deviation of the observations?
questions.solution:
When each element of a sample is multiplied by 10, the new standard deviation= 10 x original standard deviation.

The formula for standard deviation, SD = √∑(x - x̄)2/n-1.

If each element of the distribution is multiplied by 10, the new mean will become 10 times the original mean.

If all observations are multiplied by 10, then the new SD = √∑(10x-10x̄)2/n-1

= 10 √∑(x - x̄)2/n-1

= 10 x Original SD

Change in variance: variance = square of standard deviation, so when SD becomes 10 times, 

the variance will be  10² = 100 times the original variance.

Related Pearl: Variance, Deviation Scores and Standard Deviation

  • Deviation Scores: 
    • The deviation score of an element in distribution is the difference between the mean of the distribution and the element itself, i.e., subtracting the distribution’s mean from the element.
    • Denoted by the letter x
    • For example, if 29 and 15 are elements in a distribution that has a mean of 22, the deviation score of 29 would be (29 – 22) = 7 and the deviation score of 15 would be (15 – 22) = - 7.
    • Sum of all the deviation scores of elements in distribution will be zero
  • Variance (also called mean square) 
    • The mean of the squares of all the deviation scores of the distribution
    • Used to measure how far data is spread out
    • If the variance is zero, it indicates that all the elements in the distribution are the same and that there is no variability.
    • Population variance (σ2) is calculated as:
      • Find the deviation score of each element in the distribution
      • Square each of the deviation scores.
      • Obtain the mean of all these squared deviation scores
  •  
    • Sample variance (s2): 
      • more commonly used in statistics than population variance
      • The denominator is n-1 (and not N as it is in population variance)
      • For small samples, it is better to use n-1 in the denominator.
      • For a very large sample, like a population, subtracting 1 from a huge number will not make much of a significant correction. Hence, we may choose to ignore subtracting 1.
  • Standard Deviation (SD)
    • It is the square root of variance.
    • The standard deviation of a population is denoted by σ and the standard deviation of a sample is denoted by just s.
    • The formula for the standard deviation of a sample (usually <30):
    • For a population (large sample), the denominator would be replaced by just N.
    • It is particularly useful for normal distributions but can be used in skewed distributions
    • It is used to calculate the proportion of the population within the given SD
    • A low SD means that the data are close to the mean but a high SD would mean that the data are more spread out.
    • The empirical rule of a normal distribution states that:
      • Approximately 68% of the distribution falls within one standard deviation of the mean.
      • Approximately 95% of the distribution falls within two standard deviations of the mean.
      • Approximately 99.7% of the distribution falls within three standard deviations of the mean.

questions.text: A village has 100 children under the age of 5. The coverage of measles vaccination is 60%. Following a case of measles, 26 children developed measles. What is the secondary attack rate?
questions.solution:
The secondary attack rate for the given scenario is 66%.

The secondary attack rate (SAR) is given by:

(Number of exposed or susceptible persons developing the disease within the incubation period x 100)/(Total number of close or exposed contacts that are susceptible)

Here, number who developed the disease after exposure= 26

Susceptible population= 100 - 60 (vaccinated) - 1 (primary case) = 39

Therefore, SAR = 26 /39 x 100 = 66%.

SAR is a measure of communicability.

questions.text: A case-control study was done among 500 lung cancer patients and 400 controls. The study groups had 400 and 50 smokers respectively. Calculate the odds ratio.
questions.solution:
In the given scenario, the odds ratio (OR) is 28.

The given data is represented as: 

 

Disease +

Disease  -

Exposure +

400 (a)

50 (b)

Exposure -

100 (c)

350 (d)

Odds Ratio = ad/bc

= (400 x 350) / (50 x 100)

= (4 x 35)/5

= 4 x 7

= 28

Related Pearl: Odds Ratio

  • Odds ratio is a measure of the strength of association between risk factor and outcome in case control studies.
  • Odds ratio can be arrived at from case control studies.
  • It is also known as cross product ratio.
  • A representation of the odds ratio (OR) is given in the picture below:

Calculation of odds ratio (OR) = (a/b)/(c/d) = ad/bc where, 

  Cancer
Exposure   Yes No
Yes a b
No c d
  • OR < 1 indicates possible protection (negative association) as the frequency of exposure is lower among cases than controls.
  • OR = 1 indicates no association of risk with exposure, or that the event is equally likely in both groups.
  • OR > 1 indicates increased risk (positive association) as the frequency of exposure is greater among cases than controls.

questions.text: As part of the National family planning program, you are conducting a study in a village to gather data on the efficacy of a new contraceptive. 20 out of 100 women became pregnant in the village despite using this contraceptive for a period of 2 years continuously. What is the pearl index of this contraceptive?
questions.solution:
In the given scenario, the pearl index is 10 per HWY.

Here, the total number of accidental pregnancies is 20. The total months of exposure are 24 months for each woman.

Hence, the total months of exposure for 100 women are 24 x 100 = 2400.

Pearl index = Total accidental pregnancies x 1200/ Total months of exposure 

Hence, pearl index= 20 x 1200/2400 = 10 per HWY

Related Pearl: Pearl index and couple protection rate:

Pearl Index is defined as the number of contraceptive failures per 100 woman-years of exposure (HWY).

  • In this formula, the total accidental pregnancies that are used as the numerator must include every known conception, irrespective of its outcome.
  • In the denominator, total months of exposure is obtained by deducting, 10 months for full-term deliveries and 4 months for abortion, from the total period under review.

Couple Protection Rate:

  • It is an indicator of couple protection practice in the community.
  • It is defined as the percentage of eligible couples effectively protected against childbirth by one or the other approved methods of family planning.
  • Attaining a 60% CPR would mean restricting all third or higher-order births.

questions.text:
A study was conducted in a village with 180 eligible couples, to gather data on the different contraceptive methods used. The data obtained are given below. What is the couple protection rate in the village?

Vasectomy – 15

Tubectomy – 15

Intrauterine device (IUD) users – 8

Oral pill users – 15

Condom users – 7
questions.solution:
Couple protection rate (CPR) is defined as the percentage of eligible couples effectively protected against childbirth by one or the other approved methods of family planning. 

In the given scenario, 60 out of 180 eligible couples are using different contraceptive methods. Therefore, CPR = (60/180) x 100 = 33%.

Related Pearl: Pearl index and couple protection rate:

Pearl Index is defined as the number of contraceptive failures per 100 woman-years of exposure (HWY).

  • In this formula, the total accidental pregnancies that are used as the numerator must include every known conception, irrespective of its outcome.
  • In the denominator, total months of exposure is obtained by deducting, 10 months for full-term deliveries and 4 months for abortion, from the total period under review.

Couple Protection Rate:

  • It is an indicator of couple protection practice in the community.
  • It is defined as the percentage of eligible couples effectively protected against childbirth by one or the other approved methods of family planning.
  • Attaining a 60% CPR would mean restricting all third or higher-order births.

questions.text: For a community’s well water, Horrock’s apparatus first shows the 3rd cup changing color to blue. What will be the required dose of bleaching powder for disinfecting 9100 litres of water?
questions.solution:
The dose of bleaching powder required is given by (n x 2) gms for 455 litres of water, where n is the number of the first cup that shows distinct blue color.

In this scenario, the dose of bleaching powder required to disinfect 455 litres of water is (3 x 2) = 6 grams.

Since 9100/455 = 20. The amount of bleaching powder required to disinfect 9100 litres of water = 6 x 20 = 120 grams.

Related Pearl: Horrock’s Apparatus

  • Horrock’s Apparatus is used to estimate the chlorine demand of water.
  • This is widely used in the disinfection of wells to find out how much bleaching powder is required.
  • Contents of this water-testing apparatus:
    • 6 white cups of 200 ml each and one black cup with a circular mark
    • 2 metal spoons (each holds 2g of bleaching powder)
    • 7 glass stirring rods and 1 special pipette
    • Two droppers
    • Starch-iodide indicator solution
  • Procedure:
    • Use 2g of bleaching powder to create a thin paste in the black cup. It is now called the Chlorine stock solution.
    • The six white cups are filled with the water to be tested
    • Add one drop of the stock solution to the 1st cup, two drops to the 2nd cup, three drops to the 3rd cup, and so on till adding six drops to the 6th cup.
    • Stir the cups and wait for half an hour.
    • Add 3 drops of starch-iodide indicator to each cup
    • Development of blue color in the apparatus indicates free residual chlorine. 
    • The first cup which develops this color gives an estimate of the amount of bleaching powder needed to disinfect 455 Litres of the sample water.
  • Chlorine demand or the dose of bleaching powder required is given by (n x 2) g for 455 liters of water, i.e., (n x 2) g of bleaching powder is required to disinfect 455 liters of water. Here, n represents the position of the cup (1, 2, 3, etc.) that was first to show a distinct blue color.

questions.text: Arterial blood gas analysis of an unconscious woman shows pH = 7.39, PaCO2 = 20 mm Hg and Bicarbonate = 12 mEq/L. The acid-base abnormality is:
questions.solution:
In the above ABG, pH is within normal range (7.35-7.45). However, PaCO2 (Normal: 40 mmHg) and Bicarbonate (Normal: 22 mEq/L) are low.

Here, we start with the bicarbonate levels. Bicarbonate levels of 12 mEq/L indicates metabolic acidosis.

Now, we check whether the decrease in PaCO2 is within the expected range of compensation by applying Winter’s formula.

Expected PaCO2 = [1 .5 X HCO3-] + 8 ± 2

                        = [1.5 X12] + 8 ± 2

                        = 26 ± 2 mm Hg

Because the observed PaCO2 (20 mm Hg) is lower than the expected value (26± 2 mm Hg), there is a coexisting primary respiratory alkalosis.

Hence, the acid-base abnormality is Mixed metabolic acidosis-respiratory alkalosis.

We arrive at the same conclusion by starting with the low PaCO2 i.e respiratory alkalosis.

The expected compensation is calculated by the formula

Decrease in HCO3- = 0.2 x [decrease in PaCO2] (since it is acute, replace by 0.5 in chronic)

                           = 0.2 X (40-20)

                           = 0.2 X 20 = 4

Therefore, expected bicarbonate in compensatory metabolic acidosis is 22 - 4 = 18

The actual bicarbonate (12 mEq/L ) is lower than expected (18 mEq/L).This implies a co-existing metabolic acidosis.

Mixed metabolic acidosis-respiratory alkalosis is seen in Acute salicylate toxicity.

  • It leads to respiratory alkalosis by stimulating the respiratory center in the medulla and causing

tachypnea (with resultant low PaC02 as the C02 is blown off).

  • It then causes an anion gap metabolic acidosis by uncoupling of oxidative phosphorylation in the mitochondria leading to anaerobic metabolism (with resultant low HCO3- from acid buildup).

Hint: In compensated acid base disorders, the pH never reaches normal range, hence options A and B can be ruled out. Option D is ruled out because the primary acid base disorders are opposite to values of bicarbonate and PaC02 given.

questions.text:
The ABG findings of a patient are given below. Which of the following metabolic abnormality is present in this patient?

PaCO2: 35 mmHg

HCO3-: 30 mEq/L

pH: 7.50

choices.text: Metabolic alkalosis with compensatory respiratory alkalosis

questions.solution:
The given scenario reveals metabolic alkalosis and respiratory alkalosis.

Interpretation of ABG:

Step 1:

Value in the question Normal value Interpretation
pH = 7.50 (7.35 – 7.45) 7.4 Increased
paCO2 = 35  (35 – 45) 40 Normal
HCO3- = 30  (22 – 28) 25 Increased

The values clearly suggest metabolic alkalosis.

Step 2:

Calculating the respiratory compensation:

In metabolic alkalosis, Compensation formula is as follows:

∆ [HCO3-] = Increase in HCO3-, in above case is  = 30 - 25 = 5

So, compensatory increase of CO2 should be = 0.7 x 5 = 3.5

Applying the above, the compensation value of CO2 should lie between

40 + 3.5 = 43.5 or approx. 44

Taking +/- 3 into consideration,  Compensatory values of CO2 = 41 – 47

Step 3:

Since CO2 = 35 which is below the compensatory values, hence this is not compensated.

It suggests that there is a simultaneous respiratory alkalosis.

Step 4:

Looking for anion gap:

Anion gap should be looked for only in cases of:

  • Metabolic acidosis
  • Normal pH

Since the primary disorder is metabolic alkalosis, anion gap is not looked into.

A situation like this is seen with liver disease and diuretics administration.

questions.text: Calculate the rate of atrial contraction from the given ECG strip:
questions.solution:
The rate of atrial contraction is 375/min.

Atril Flutter

The ECG depicts atrial flutter with a 4:1 block.

Calculation:

  • No. of large boxes between two R waves = 3
  • Hence, ventricular rate = 300/3 = 100/min
  • As it is a 4:1 block, for every 4 atrial contractions there is 1 ventricular contraction
  • Hence, atrial rate = 100 x 4 = 400/min
  • Hence, nearest correct answer is 375/min

Alternative calculation:

  • No. of small boxes between two R waves = 16
  • Hence, ventricular rate = 1500/16 = 94
  • As it is a 4:1 block, for every 4 atrial contractions there is 1 ventricular contraction.
  • Hence, atrial rate = 94 x 4 = 376/min

questions.text:
Calculate the transferrin saturation if:

Serum iron - 130 μg/mL TIBC - 320 μg/mL
questions.solution:
Transferrin saturation = (Serum iron)/(Total iron binding capacity) × 100

                                =  130/320 × 100

                                = 40.625%

So Transferrin saturation = 40.6%

questions.text: A 26-year-old man was rushed to the ER after a motorbike accident causing a head injury. He was confused, could open eyes on command and was withdrawing on painful stimuli. His GCS score is __________
questions.solution:
Since the patient is

  • Confused – V4
  • Opens eye on command – E3
  • Withdraws to painful stimuli – M4

Therefore the GCS score is 4+3+4 =11.

Related Pearl: Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS)

GCS Score

  • 13-15 represent mild injury
  • 9-12 represent moderate injury
  • Scores ≤8 represent severe injury 

Head Injury Severity: Clinical classification 

Eyes Opening

 Score
Spontaneously 4
To verbal command 3
To painful stimulus 2
Do not open 1

Non-testable

 NT

 

Verbal response Score
Normal-oriented conversation 5
Confused 4
Inappropriate words only 3
Sounds only 2
No sounds 1

Non-testable

 NT

 

Motor Response Score
Obeys commands 6
Localizes to pain 5
Withdrawal response to pain 4
Abnormal flexion/ Decorticate posturing  3
Abnormal extension/ Decerebrate posturing  2
No motor response 1

Non-testable

 NT

Minimum value: 3

Maximum value: 15

  • GCS, in particular, the motor score, is the best predictor of neurological outcome.
  • If an area cannot be assessed, no numerical score is given for that region, and it is considered “non-testable." (NT)
  • In case of endotracheal intubation or tracheostomy, the verbal component of the score is denoted as NT.
  • A score of  ‘1’ is not recorded in missing components, instead, NT is used
  • when a component is Not Testable, a total score is not recorded because the score will be low and this could be confusing to medical colleagues. This may also imply that the patient is more unwell than they actually are.

 

NOTE: 

A new parameter, "pupil reactivity score" has been added to GCS, and now, it is referred to as GCS-P.

P stands for "Pupils unreactive to light"

Pupils unreactive to light Score
Both pupils 2
One pupil 1 
Neither  0

The pupillary score is subtracted from the GCS score to give the final value. Therefore, the range of GCS-P is 1–15.

Note: The minimum frequency of observations for patients with GCS equal to 15 should be as follows, starting after the initial assessment in the emergency department:

  • Half-hourly for 2 hours,
  • Then 1-hourly for 4 hours,
  • 2-hourly thereafter.

Should the patient with GCS equal to 15 deteriorate at any time after the initial 2-hour period, observations should revert to half-hourly and follow the original frequency schedule.

Related Pearl: NICE Guidelines for CT in Head Injury

National Institute for Health and Care Excellence (NICE) Guidelines for Computed Tomography (CT) in Head Injury

Indications for CT imaging within 1 hour of the following risk factors being identified:

  • Glasgow Coma Score (GCS) <12 on initial assessment
  • GCS <15 at 2 hours after injury on assessment in an emergency department
  • Focal neurological deficit
  • Suspected open, depressed, or basal skull fracture
  • More than one episode of vomiting
  • Post-traumatic seizure

Indications for CT imaging within 8 hours:

  • Age >65 years
  • Bleeding or clotting disorders
  • Dangerous mechanism of injury (e.g., fall from a height of >1 meter/5 stairs, road traffic accident)
  • Retrograde amnesia >30 minutes

questions.text: A 12 year old girl presents to the emergency department after sustaining electrical burn injuries of 10% total body surface area. Her bodyweight is 40 kg. What is the amount of fluid that must be administered within the first 8 hours after burn injury?
questions.solution:
In electrical injuries, adjusted fluid rates are given at a rate of 4ml LR x kg x %TBSA until urine clears.

The calculated fluid volume is initiated in the following manner: (a 40-kg girl with 10% TBSA burns requires 4 × 40 × 10 = 1,600 mL in 24 hours).

One-half of that volume (800 mL) should be provided in the first 8 hours.

The remaining one-half of the total fluid is administered during the subsequent 16 hours.

In electric injury, the current enters at one point and then leaves the body at an exit point, usually to the earth or the neutral conductor of the electricity supply. It tends to take the shortest route between entry and best exit, irrespective of the varying conductivity of different internal tissues.

When a hand is brought into contact with a live conductor, and the body is earthed either through the feet or the opposite hand, the most common passage of current is across the heart.

It has been claimed that the most dangerous current path is contacted with the right hand and exit through the left foot, as this causes the maximum (up to 8.5 percent) of the total body current to flow through the heart when compared with head to feet (up to 5.9 percent), left hand to feet (up to 5.1 percent), hand to hand (up to 4.4 percent) or foot to foot (up to 0.4 percent)

Direct current (d.c.) is less dangerous than alternating current (a.c.). Most deaths from electricity are from cardiac arrhythmias, usually, ventricular fibrillation ending in cardiac arrest.

Related Pearl: Burns – Formulae for Fluid Calculation(Updated according to ATLS 10th edition 2018 guidelines)

Parkland’s formula gives the total fluid requirement for 24hours. Half of this volume is infused in the first 8 hours, and the remaining half is infused in the next 16 hours.

This formula is recommended for those who have sustained large deep partial-thickness or full-thickness burns that cover more than 20% of the TBSA in adults and more than 10% in children. 

Formulas provide a starting target rate; Subsequently, the amount of fluid provided should be adjusted based on urine output.

Category of burn Age Amount of Ringer’s Lactate given for 24 hours (ml) Target urine output (ml/kg/hour)
2nd/3rd-degree burns Adults  2 x weight in kgs x % TBSA 0.5
<14 years 3 x weight in kgs x % TBSA 1
< 1 year or <30kgs 3 x weight in kgs x % TBSA + 5% dextrose on a maintenance rate 1
4th-degree burns / Electrical burns All ages 4 x weight in kgs x % TBSA 1-1.5 (until urine clears)

Dextrose maintenance:

  • 100 ml/ kg in 24 hours for 10 kg
  • 50 ml/kg for next 10 kg
  • 20 ml/kg for every kg after 20 kg

Evan’s formula is used for normal saline.

For the first 24 hours:

  • Amount of NS administered = weight in kgs x % TBSA
  • Amount of colloid administered = weight in kgs x % TBSA
  • 5% Dextrose administered= 2000 ml

After 24 hours, the amount of NS and colloid administered is half. 2000 ml of dextrose is maintained.

Muir and Barclay’s formula for colloids:

  • 1 portion of colloid = (weight in kgs x % TBSA)/2
  • 6 portions of colloid are administered over 36 hours

questions.text: A woman whose obstetric score is G2 P1 L1 had an LMP of Jan 9th 2017. Calculate the EDD according to Naegele’s rule.
questions.solution:
As per Naegele’s rule, the EDD (expected date of delivery) of this woman is October 16, 2017.

Naegele’s rule states that EDD is obtained by adding 7 days and subtracting 3 months from the LMP (the 1st day of the last menstrual period). Another method is adding 9 months and 7 days to LMP. Less than 5% of births follow Naegele's rule. 

It is based on a 28-day regular cycle. If the cycle is shorter/longer than 28 days, corrected EDD is calculated as follows:

  • For a 35-day cycle, add another 7 (35-28=7) days to the calculated EDD to get the corrected EDD.
  • For a 25-day cycle, subtract 3 (28-25=3) days from the calculated EDD to get the corrected EDD.

Naegele’s rule cannot be followed in IVF pregnancies. Considering the human embryo takes 266 days to develop, EDD is calculated in IVF pregnancies by the following method:

  • Same day as fertilization (day 0): EDD = date of transfer + 266 days 
  • 3 days after fertilization (day 3): EDD = date of transfer + 263 days
  • 5 days after fertilization (day 5): EDD = date of transfer + 261 days

questions.text: A primigravida came to the labor room at 40 weeks + 5 days gestation for induction of labor. On per vaginal examination, the cervix is 1 cm dilated and is 30% effaced. The vertex is at –1 station and the cervix is soft and posterior. What will be the bishop score for this lady?
questions.solution:
The Bishop's score, in this case, is 5.

Bishop’s pre-induction Cervical Scoring System.

Score

Cervix 

 0 1 2 3
Dilatation (cm) Closed  1-2 3-4  >5 
Effacement (%) 0-30 40-50 60-70 ≥80
Consistency  Firm Medium Soft     - 
Position  Posterior  Midline  Anterior       -
Head station  -3 -2 -1,0 +1, +2

Total score = 13; Favorable score = 6-13; Unfavorable score = 0-5

In the modified Bishop score (1991) the effacement is replaced by cervical length in cm.

Score 0 1 2 3
Cervical length in (cm) More than 4 2-4 1-2 Less than 1 

From the data given in the question:

  • Cervical dilatation is 1 cm, hence score = 1.
  • Effacement is 30%, hence score = 0
  • Station of the head is –1, hence score = 2
  • Consistency of cervix is soft, hence score = 2
  • Position of the cervix is posterior, hence score = 0

Hence, Bishop's score is 1+0+2+2+0 = 5.

Related Pearl: Bishop’s Score (Modified)

Score 0 1 2 3
Dilatation (cm) Closed 1-2 3-4 5+
Cervical length (cm) >4 2-4 1-2 <1
Consistency Firm Medium Soft -
Position Posterior Midline Anterior -
Head-Station -3 -2 -1, 0 +1, +2

Total score = 13

Favourable= 6-13

Unfavourable= 0-5

Note: 

  • According to NICE guidelines, a score of 6-13 is favorable for induction of labour.
  • According to Williams Obstetrics (26th edition), a score of 9 or more indicates a high likelihood of successful induction.

Related Pearl: Indications & contraindications for induction of labor

Indications:
  • Uncontrolled maternal diabetes mellitus
  • Gestational hypertension
  • Pre-eclampsia
  • Post-term pregnancy
  • Abruption placentae
  • Premature rupture of membranes
  • Rh-isoimmunization
  • Intra-uterine growth restriction (IUGR)
  • Intra-uterine death (IUD)
  • Oligohydramnios
Contraindications:
  • Contracted/distorted pelvis and cephalopelvic disproportion
  • Placenta previa or vasa previa
  • Active genital herpes
  • Pelvic tumor & carcinoma cervix
  • Transverse lie or footling breech
  • Appreciable macrosomia
  • Severe hydrocephalus
  • Umbilical cord prolapse
  • High-risk pregnancy with fetal compromise
  • Previous classical cesarean or hysterotomy
  • Previous history of uterine rupture
  • Pelvic surgeries like vesicovaginal fistula/rectovaginal fistula/pelvic floor repair (third or fourth-degree perineal tears repair)
  • Previous 3 or more lower transverse cesarian sections.

questions.text: You have been asked to start parenteral iron infusion for a woman at 38 weeks of gestation. What formula would you use to calculate the required dosage?
questions.solution:
The formula for calculating dose of parenteral iron is:

Total dose in mg =  2.4 X (Target Hb - Actual Hb) X Body Wt. + 500 mg

  • 2.4 - conversion factor
  • Target Hb - Hb you want to achieve 
  • Actual Hb- level of current Hb
  • 500 mg - additional amount to replenish the iron stores

Iron sucrose must be diluted only using normal saline at a concentration of 1-2 mg of iron/mL of saline. It is given over 20-30 minutes intravenously.

questions.text: If the fundal height of the uterus is 35 cm and the head is at -2 station, what is the approximate fetal weight?
questions.solution:
The approximate fetal weight is 3.5 kg.

Estimated fetal weight (EFW) from fundal height and station of the head is given by the Johnson formula:

  • If station is below ischial spine: EFW = [height(in cm)-11] x 155
  • If station is at or above ischial spine: EFW = [height(in cm)-12] x 155

The above formula gives the estimated fetal weight in grams.

The station of the head is zero if the presenting part is at the level of ischial spines.

The station is stated in negative values (-1, -2, etc) if the head is above ischial spines and in positive values (+1, +2, etc) if the head is below ischial spines.

Now, applying the formula;

  • Station of the head is -2 (above the ischial spine); height is 35 cm
  • EFW = (35-12)x 155 = 3565 grams = 3.56 kgs

Note: Shephard formula and Hadlock formula are used to measure fetal weight from USG by fetal biometry.

questions.text: A 4 year old child is brought to the casualty in respiratory distress. In order to intubate this child, which is the appropriate size of endotracheal tube to be used?
questions.solution:
Appropriate size of an endotracheal tube for a 4 year old child is 5mm.

Size of an endotracheal tube usually refers to the internal diameter in mm.

According to the Penlington formula, size of the endotracheal tube in the pediatric population is calculated by: 

<6 years: 3.75 + [Age/3]  

>6 years: 4.5 + [Age/4]  

The appropriate size of the endotracheal tube for this child is 5 mm ( 3.75 + [4/3] ) = 3.75 + 1.33 = 5.05. 

Age Internal diameter (mm) Length (cm)
Full term infant 3.5 12
Child 4  + (Age/4)    12 + (Age/2)
Adult female 7.0–7.5   

  20-22
Adult male  7.5–9.0     22-24

 

Besides age, choice of an endotracheal tube also depends on the presence of airway pathologies and the reason behind placement of the tube.

Smaller sized tubes lead to increase airway resistance and increased work of breathing. 

Larger tubes have a higher risk of sore throat, laryngeal and tracheal trauma.

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy weighing 30 Kgs has been posted for surgical resection of a tumor. What is the daily maintenance fluid required for this child while he’s NPO?
questions.solution:
The daily maintenance fluid required for a child weighing 30 Kg is 1700 ml. 

Bodyweight method for calculating the daily maintenance fluid volume (also known as Holliday-Segar method) is used.

Bodyweight Fluid required per day
0–10 Kg 100 mL/Kg
11–20 Kg 1000 mL + 50 mL/Kg for each Kg >10 Kg
>20 Kg 1500 mL + 20 mL/Kg for each Kg >20 kg

Calculation:

In the question, the weight of the child is given as 30 Kgs.

So, the formula for >20 Kg is used.

1500 mL + (20 mL x weight more than 20 Kgs)

Since the child weight is 30 Kgs, he/she is 10 Kgs more.

Therefore, fluid required is

= 1500 mL + (20 mL x 10)

= 1500 mL + 200 mL

= 1700 mL.
